DOC.HEAD: Loses $330.4 Million in Quarter, $1.46 Billion in Year
DOC.TEXT: Southmark Corp., one of the biggest companies to seek bankruptcy-court protection because of a default on junk bond debt, said Thursday lower property sales and higher interest costs led to a $330.4 million quarterly loss. For the fiscal year, the real estate and financial services firm lost $1.46 billion, due mainly a $962 million provision for losses. The company also said its San Jacinto Savings Association, a thrift on which officials have based much of their recovery hopes, was $21.2 million short of the required capital as of Sept. 30. Southmark said it is negotiating with federal regulatory officials over the future of San Jacinto, one of the largest thrifts in Texas. Southmark was one of the fastest-growing companies in Texas but faltered badly because of an excessive reliance on debt, particularly the use of financing with high-yield, high-risk junk bonds. It went into technical default on $700 million in junk bond obligations earlier this year and sought protection from creditors in bankruptcy court in July. Southmark said the $330.4 million loss in the quarter ended June 30 amounted to $7.51 per share, compared with a $138.32 million loss in the comparable period. Revenue in the quarter dropped from $539.75 million to $287.15 million. The fiscal year loss, which amounted to $33.16 per share, compared with fiscal 1988's loss of $125.12 million, or $3.60 per share. Revenues in the year declined form $1.86 billion to $1.79 billion. Southmark has said in bankruptcy filings that it had assets of $866.5 million and debts of $1.51 billion.
